sen.j: 千々石 ミゲル（ちぢわ みげる、Miguel 永禄12年（1569年）頃 - 寛永9年12月14日（1633年1月23日）?）は、安土桃山時代から江戸時代初期のキリシタンで、天正遣欧少年使節の正使。
sen.e: Miguel CHIJIWA (Miguel 1569 - January 23, 1633?) was a Christian who was one of the senior envoy of Tensho Keno Shonen Shisetsu (the Tensho Boy Mission to Europe) who lived during the Azuchi Momoyama Period to the early Edo Period.

sen.e: He was the son of Noukazu CHIJIWA, a feudal lord of Hizen Province.

sen.j: 有馬晴信の従兄弟で、大村純忠の甥。
sen.e: He was cousins with Harunobu ARIMA, and a niece of Sumitada OMURA.

sen.j: 千々石直員の子として生まれた千々石ミゲルは1580年に洗礼を受け、司祭になるべく、有馬のセミナリヨに入って学んでいた。
sen.e: Miguel CHIJIWA who was born to Noukazu CHIJIWA, was baptized in 1580, and entered Seminario (Seminary) and had been studying to become a priest.

sen.j: そのころ、巡察師として日本を訪れたアレッサンドロ・ヴァリニャーノ（ヴァリニャーニ）はキリシタン大名であった大村純忠と知り合い、財政難に陥っていた日本の布教事業を立て直すため、また次代を担う邦人司祭育成のため、キリシタン大名の名代となる使節をローマに派遣しようと考えた。
sen.e: Alessandro Valignano (Valignano) who came to Japan as a Jesuit visitor, met with Sumitada OMURA, a Christian daimyo (Christian feudal lord), and in order to restore missionary work that was in financial difficulties, and to nurture Japanese priests which would take charge of the coming generation, he sought to dispatch an envoy representing Christian daimyo to Rome.

sen.j: そこでヴァリニャーノに白羽の矢をたてられたのが、セミナリヨで学んでいた四人の少年たちであった。
sen.e: Therefore, Valignano marked out four boys who were studying at the Seminario (Seminary).

sen.j: その選考基準は容姿端麗であり、長旅に耐える健康を備え、語学や勉学においてすぐれていることであった。
sen.e: Criteria for selecting the representatives were good looks, health that can withstand a long trip, and outstanding aptitude for foreign languages and studies.

sen.j: また正使の二人はあくまでキリシタン大名の名代ということで、彼らとの血縁にあたるものが選ばれている。
sen.e: The two senior envoy were selected merely as substitutes for Christian daimyo (Christian feudal lord) who were related to them.

sen.j: 1590年、日本に戻ってきた彼らは1591年、聚楽第で豊臣秀吉と謁見した。
sen.e: A year after their return to Japan in 1590, they had an audience with Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in Jurakudai residence.

sen.j: 秀吉は彼らを気に入り、仕官を勧めたが、彼らはみなそれを断った。
sen.e: Hideyoshi took a liking to them, and recommended that they become officers, but they all had declined.

sen.e: Later, he went to Noviciado in Amakusa in order to continue studying to become a priest, and went to collegio(college established by the Jesuits) to continue with his studies.

sen.j: 1593年7月25日、他の三人と共にイエズス会に入会。
sen.e: On August 11, 1593 he joined the Society of Jesus with the other three members of the envoy.

sen.j: 1601年には既にイエズス会を退会して、清左衛門と名乗っていたことがわかっている。
sen.e: He withdrew from the Society of Jesus by 1601, and referred to himself as Seizaemon.

sen.j: 彼はその後結婚し、信仰も捨てて長崎で暮らしていたが、後半生はさまざまな苦難に会い、従兄弟にあたる大村喜前や有馬晴信からも疎まれ、晴信の家臣に暴行され、失意のうちにこの世を去った。
sen.e: He later married, renounced his religion, and lived in Nagasaki, but faced many ordeals; Yoshiaki OTOMO and Harunobu ARIMA who were his cousins hated him, a retainer of Harunobu assaulted him, and he died broken-hearted.

sen.j: ミゲルが信仰を捨てた理由は定かではないが、マルチノはラテン語の才能を評価されてイエズス会の日本管区区長として長崎へ行き、マンショとジュリアンは神学をより奥深く学ぶ為にマカオへ留学した。
sen.e: It is not known why Miguel renounced religion, but Martinho went to Nagasaki as a ward mayor of Japanese district of the Society of Jesus owing to his talent in Latin, and Mancio and Julian went to Macao to study Theology thoroughly.

sen.e: However, Miguel who was physically weak and not as industrious, was not given permission to study abroad, and it is conjectured that he renounced himself from the Society of Jesus as a result of his anger or jealousy toward this.

sen.e: A graveyard which is thought to be of Seizaemon and his wife built by his son Genba, was found in 2003 (Kazuhisa OISHI announced it on February 28 of the same year) at Tarami-cho, Nishisonogi-gun, Nagasaki Prefecture (the present Isahaya City).
